title: Shift tests
body:
I don't how to read https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/u/1/d/1xat7UI8GtB4ZGVdlK5_XQSHJZaMThi4SrlcL8XMZb5Q/htmlview#, but this is my set of the following combination:

- values:
   - 0b0
   - 0b1
   - 0b101
   - 0b100000...
   - 0b101000...
   - 0b010101...
   - 0b101010...

- shift amounts:
   - 0
   - 1
   - 2
   - 254
   - 255
   - 256
   - 257
   - 0xfff...fff
   - 0xfff...ffe

This gives 7 * 9 * 3 == 189 test cases, but you can group them squeeze into smaller number of contracts. E.g. for every shift opcode create a contract that does all of these combinations and place them in separated storage slots. I.e.
```
storage[0] = 0 << 0
storage[1] = 0 << 1
storage[2] = 0 << 2
...
```

is it correct for the first iteration? 

```
sar (0x0b0, 0)
shl (0x0b0, 0)
shr (0x0b0, 0)
```

what `...` at the end means?

The `0b` means the binary notation (as in C++).
The `...` means to repeat patterns or zeros. E.g. `0x101000,,,` means to add zeros up to 256 bits so only the most significant and 3rd significant bits are 1, rest is 0. For `0b01010101...` means to repeat `01` pattern to the end. In hex it is all 5s: `0x55555...55555`.

> is it correct for the first iteration?
> 
> ```
> sar (0x0b0, 0)
> shl (0x0b0, 0)
> shr (0x0b0, 0)
> ```

Yes.
Yes. Typo: ~~6~~5.

https://github.com/ethereum/tests/pull/574
by iterating 
```
for each values
   for each amount
         sar (val, amount)
         shl (val, amount)
         shr (val, amount)
```

if got this:

```
"0x04" : "0x01",
                                "0x05" : "0x01",
                                "0x06" : "0x01",

                                "0x1b" : "0xfffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffe",

                                "0x23" : "0x04",
                                "0x24" : "0x01",
                                "0x25" : "0x7f",
                                "0x26" : "0x01fc",
                                "0x27" : "0x7f",
                                "0x28" : "0x7f",
                                "0x29" : "0x01fe",
                                "0x2a" : "0x7f",

                                "0x2c" : "0x0200",
                                "0x2d" : "0x80",
                                "0x2e" : "0x80",
                                "0x2f" : "0x0202",
                                "0x30" : "0x80",
                                "0x31" : "0xffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffff",
                                "0x32" : "0xfffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffe",
                                "0x33" : "0x7fffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffff",
                                "0x34" : "0xffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffff",
                                "0x35" : "0xfffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffc",
                                "0x36" : "0x7fffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffff",
                                "0x3b" : "0x20",
                                "0x3e" : "0x40",
                                "0x40" : "0x07",
                                "0x41" : "0x1fc0",
                                "0x42" : "0x07",
                                "0x43" : "0x07",
                                "0x44" : "0x1fe0",
                                "0x45" : "0x07",
                                "0x46" : "0x08",
                                "0x47" : "0x2000",
                                "0x48" : "0x08",
                                "0x49" : "0x08",
                                "0x4a" : "0x2020",
                                "0x4b" : "0x08",
                                "0x4c" : "0xffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffff",
                                "0x4d" : "0xffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffe0",
                                "0x4e" : "0x07ffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffff",
                                "0x4f" : "0xffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffff",
                                "0x50" : "0xffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffc0",
                                "0x51" : "0x07ffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffff",
                                "0x67" : "0xffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffff",

```
Something is wrong. The first value is 0, so the first 9x3 slots should be all zeros.

looks like sar (0, 2) return 2   `lll (SAR 0 2)`

```
"0x0118" : "0x1000001d",
"0x0119" : "0x80",
"0x011a" : "0x02",
"0x011b" : "0x02",
```

could it be argument order misinterpretation? Just in case I rewrite test to run each values with each amount  and vice versa.
There is the arguments swap in `lll`. Shift opcodes are using different argument order than in SUB, DIV, etc.

so is this looking ok? 
https://github.com/ethereum/tests/pull/574/commits/bfe523ccf1babebf610ed727e6eab42ed004c010#diff-9b911bce8130192f701b7c1f32f8a755R2038

> so is this looking ok?

Yes, because it's `0 >> 0xaaaaa....`.
LLL issue reported: https://github.com/ethereum/solidity/issues/5714.
good. that means that implementation is correct anyway. I will just recompile the test after lll is fixed.
LLL is not broken, `(shl x y)` is a macro, doesn't even use the opcode. Just use assembly or assembly in LLL: `(asm shl x y)`
`(SHL x y)` is different from `(SSTORE x y)`  ?
Of course, one of them does shift, the other does sstore.
I mean in the way how lll is putting arguments in the stack

There is this list of "builtin" macros: https://github.com/ethereum/solidity/blob/develop/liblll/CompilerState.cpp#L45

If the keyword is matched, such as `shl`, it uses this, otherwise it tries to use it as an "assembly instruction".
